title: 110_s1042
content: The "Consistency, Accuracy, Responsibility, and Excellence in Medical Imaging and Radiation Therapy Act of 2007" aims to enhance healthcare quality by improving the safety and precision of medical imaging and radiation therapy, reducing duplication of services, and lowering costs. It amends the Public Health Service Act to address the quality of medical imaging and radiation therapy. The "Consistency, Accuracy, Responsibility, and Excellence in Medical Imaging and Radiation Therapy Act of 2007" establishes standards for the safety and accuracy of medical imaging and radiation therapy services, focusing on personnel rather than equipment. Expert advisers are selected to provide balanced input from all healthcare sectors involved in these services. The "Consistency, Accuracy, Responsibility, and Excellence in Medical Imaging and Radiation Therapy Act of 2007" sets standards for personnel in medical imaging and radiation therapy services. The Secretary is limited in taking actions that would require state licensure for technical service providers. Exemptions include physicians, nurse practitioners, and physician assistants. Individuals must comply with the standards before performing these services. The "Consistency, Accuracy, Responsibility, and Excellence in Medical Imaging and Radiation Therapy Act of 2007" establishes standards for personnel in therapy services. Compliance can be demonstrated through certification, licensure, examination, coursework, experience, or other methods approved by the Secretary. Standards may vary by discipline and reflect expert consensus on excellence in practice. The Act establishes standards for therapy services personnel, which may vary by discipline and allow exemptions based on scope of practice. The Secretary will recognize individuals with extensive practical experience through regulation. The Secretary will certify approved bodies by a specified date. The Secretary will certify approved bodies for accreditation of compliance mechanisms with established standards, including recordkeeping and conflict of interest standards. The Secretary may require nonprofit organizations seeking certification to provide assurances of compliance with standards and timely notification of any failures. The Secretary can withdraw certification if the organization fails to meet the standards. The withdrawal of certification of an approved body does not affect the certification status of individuals or persons certified by that body. State standards for licensure, accreditation, and examinations are deemed compliant unless the Secretary determines otherwise. States can appeal determinations made by the Secretary. The Secretary may evaluate approved bodies periodically and report to the Senate and House committees. States can require higher education and training standards. Individuals providing mammogram services must meet Mammography Quality Standards Act requirements. The Secretary will promulgate regulations to ensure medical imaging and radiation therapy programs comply with standards. Alternative standards may apply in rural or underserved areas designated by the Medicare Geographic Classification Review Board. The Secretary can develop alternative standards for rural or health professional shortage areas to ensure access to quality medical imaging. States can reject these standards with proper notice. Implementation regulations must be in place within 18 months of the section's enactment. The Secretary will establish regulations for implementing standards in this section, excluding those in subsection (d)(2), within 18 months. Minimum standards for certification of approved bodies will be set within 24 months, and regulations for service delivery or payment will be promulgated within 36 months. Federal assistance may be withheld if necessary. The Secretary will establish regulations for implementing standards within 18 months. Minimum standards for certification of approved bodies will be set within 24 months. Federal assistance may be withheld if necessary. Definitions for approved body and medical imaging are provided in this section. Medical imaging involves the use of various techniques like ionizing radiation, radiopharmaceuticals, magnetic resonance, or ultrasound to produce images for disease progression. The term 'perform' refers to directly exposing a patient to radiation or positioning them for imaging or therapy. The term 'plan' relates to the preparation for medical imaging or therapy. The term 'plan' in medical imaging or radiation therapy involves preparing for a procedure by customizing it for the patient based on specific information. Radiation therapy is any procedure using radiation for disease treatment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report on the effects of the Act, including the impact of standards on diagnostic accuracy and patient safety, provider types, availability and cost of services, and data contribution requirements from entities reimbursed for technical services.
